review_title: If you like the work you do...

cons: The Health System believes it is the only game in town (the words straight from an HR rep), so there is no real push to care about employee morale. I like the work, but anything that is outside of my daily tasks is a chore.

pros: Pay, patient population, teaching hospital, IV/phlebotomy teams, active charge RN's, RN:patient ratio, coffee shop in cafeteria.

cons: I worked for the Donald Trump of physics and endured a toxic workplace where co-workers trash your tickets and talk about guns all day.   Clocking in and out as if we're hourly, charged for using the coffee maker. Hacked email systems and archaic practices, HIPAA witch hunts. Some examples include wanting to use PTO for a team-building event. And if you’re going to further your career, the Comm School doesn't admit UVa employees for their MSMIT program.

pros: you have a job and get paid

The top level where the senior staff is (CEO, CFO, COO, etc.) seem to be unaware of the daily struggles at the bottom level.

If I work a holiday I get 8 hours comp time, plus whatever comp time the governor grants state employees at end of year. We also do not have to use our time for holidays, which typically range from 8-13 per year.
cons: If you are a long term employee in the same position and/or department expect new hires to make more then you. I’ve discovered that I was 5k below the market for my position twice now during my employment.

pros:
- One day of PTO per pay period, adding up about 5 weeks per year 
- Decent pay 
- yearly evaluations with raises (haven't gotten mine yet, so not sure how the raise will be)
- Large workplace with lots of other departments and job opportunities
cons:
- Frustrating time off policy- PTO is not separate from sick days or holidays, so you must use PTO for those as well. If you have to use PTO for emergencies, say goodbye to your vacation time. 
- Only two people allowed to be off at a time, which is ridiculous when you work in a department with 40+ people 
Pharmacy is open 24/7 365, so I had to work Christmas, Mother's day, Memorial day, and Easter.

pros: It’s a job. Good benefits, OK pay .
cons:
I guess it depends on the unit you working at. The hospital, in general is not friendly. All the nurses talking smack about each other and have the fake smile on. Nurses think of themselves as intelligent, smart, thin, and thin that Patient tech are stupid and fat. Doctors are another story. They think everybody is stupid and they know everything.
This miscommunication and misunderstanding of staff to each other makes the job way harder than what it seems. Management sits in their office and write positive reviews for nurses that been in private dinner with, bad reviews for nurses who are not invited to that dinner party. (It’s a good ole girls club) and Patient Techs not invited. In addition to that, there is a competition between old nurses who are not willing to retire, or go to nursing home “since they are over 70 years old each” and the new nurses who they want to prove to their supervisors that they actually working. 
The nurse supervisors surround themselves with “Trusted” nurses who are “Spying” on other nurses, Techs and make a good tea party conversation about it. 
No parking at all

review_title: Draconian and hypocritical. Lacking in ethics and training.
pros: Opportunities to have great interactions with patients and other medical professionals. The health insurance premiums are low and the plan is good as long as you're not on the basic/high deductible plan. Retirement benefits are very good.
cons:
Attendance policies are draconian. Almost unheard of to have hourly pharmacists that have to punch a clock... I get paid six figures and am trusted to handle dangerous and costly medications but can't be trusted to get to work on time. They don't adhere to their own values and management will never admit when they've made a mistake, they believe they're infallible. It is a culture of fear. The bureaucracy is miles thick and ideas that will save money AND improve patient care will got shot down by asinine policies and red tape. Vacation policy is not great, ZERO paid holidays, you have to use your PTO for everything. 

Manager was very inexperienced and complaints to HR were not acted upon appropriately. In fact employee relations staff in HR were rude, insensitive and unprofessional; their actions made it clear they were only interested in what they thought was good for the company and not the employees. 

This place will use and abuse you because of its prestigious name because they know people will jump at the chance to work there.

pros: Level I Trauma Center, beginning to be noticed for the research it does. The focus on safety is turning around a lot of the issues for patients and staff.
cons: Allows bullying to exist without efforts to stop it. Employees must pay for parking. Managers have little respect from upper management and are afraid of making changes for fear of losing their jobs which happens frequently.

pros:
As state employees, 
Very secure
Effectively have access to two 401k's if maxing out one isn't enough
Pay is public information 

Otherwise,
Work with smart people 
Good place to retire
cons:
As state employees,
Minimal raises, no bonuses 
Pay is public information 

As UVA Health emoloyees,
Parking. In few other areas is it demonstrated as clearly that employees are an afterthought. 
Leadership is in transition and will likely not fill key roles until 2021.

As IT/support staff,
Minimal opportunity for advancement
Much work is generated by MDs with perspectives no larger than a single department, or coalitions with a single objective

review_title: Not a horrible place to work, but was glad to leave
pros: UVA has a great staff of excellent nurses and physicians.  I was proud to be a part of such expertise and knowledge.  The nursing staff were some of the most educated and proficient I've ever worked with.  The physicians were overall very collaborative with the nursing staff and I felt supported by the attending physicians at all times.
cons: Collaboration across departments was rare and each nursing unit felt that they were truly the only ones who mattered.  Department transfers of patients was almost never smooth and the sense of isolation was very uncomfortable.

review_title: My experience doing cancer research at UVa has been satisfying and fulfilling.
pros: Performing cancer research is very challenging intellectually and very rewarding because the advances made in my research have the potential to lead to improvements in cancer therapy. In my current lab, my supervisor is extremely helpful to me in my work and cares very much about his workers and this helps me to be productive and to enjoy my work.
cons: The parking system here is a major hassle. I have to pay over $200 a year to park in a remote lot, and then wait on shuttle buses (which are almost always late) to drive me to my building. It takes too much time and it is frustrating to deal with every day.

pros: I love being a nurse and caring for my patients. Benefits are pretty good. There are some who care about their employees.
cons: Some departments treat employees as just a body, whether they do great work or not.  Can be scary when there are nurses who just care about what's on their smartphone and social media instead of their patients. Yes, parking can be a problem as mentioned, but that's not number one. Poor management is probably number 1.

job_title: Nursing Professional Development Specialist in Charlottesville, VA
pros: There are many jobs available here, with increasing complexity and technology.
cons: Leadership in general is poorly trained and not generally held accountable for outcomes. Doctors are favored over all others. There is a strongly patriarchal culture. Accountability is lacking. For such a large academic medical center, processes are shockingly inadequate. Human Resources is completely ineffective.  There is also a culture of reactivity instead of one of proactivity. All effort goes into putting bandaids on hemorrhaging systems. Turnover in the nursing division is extremely high with use of many travel nurses, and still there is poor staffing. There are no budgetary reserves for educational facilities, equipment or other resources for nurses and other patient care staff (plenty for doctors however).

review_title: Good company to work for in healthcare around the Greater Albemarle area.
pros:
Good medical insurance with accommodations for quick appointments if your provider is within UVA Health system. 
Benefits/discounts with local shops, restaurants, etc.
Responsive HR. 
Friendly staff in outpatient settings (where I worked).
Flexible PTO.
cons:
Many changes/regulations from higher up supposedly for improvement in patient care but often complicate and impede patient care.
Heavy workload as patients often come in from all around Virginia and neighboring states.

pros: I am only working here for the health insurance. I already live in Charlottesville and they are a major employer in the area.
cons:
Low Pay: I am actually in the poverty line.

You have to pay for parking: I actually have to pay my employer in order to work for them!

Employee retention: Transient workforce. Most realize they can make more some place else. They would rather depend on travel nurses than keep what they have.

Training Program: Very Poor. I wish it was  rigorous. I wish they have a training to train the trainor.

Expensive area: I lived in DC and made 5 times of what I am making here. Food and housing is as expensive as the D.C. Suburbs but the pay is 5 times less. Charlottesville is very expensive and elitist! I don't live in the boonies but most of my coworkers live far out or live in group housing.

review_title: Could be great if the organization valued loyal employees
pros: Amazing opportunities to learn the newest methods of delivery in health care and increase your skill set! Great benefits and they have recently been addressing employee "perks" such as reduced cost tickets to events, discounts to local businesses, gym memberships, etc. Very close link to the university programs - I took advantage of the excellent academic programs at the university to advance my education/career.
cons: Sadly, the medical center does not value its employees enough to be transparent or just when it comes to advancement or compensation. Therefore, they are continually losing highly qualified, experienced individuals and paying a high cost literally and figuratively - turn over is crazy! They will pay a new graduate very close to what they pay a long time employee so there is no incentive to stay. Many stories of employees that leave and then return in order to get competitive pay as a new recruit. They value new recruits much more than current employees - stories are endless: 30 year employees not eligible for any cost of living increases for over a decade because the pay grade ceiling has been met and never raised, current employees making several dollars an hour less than new hires with less experience, not rewarding employees for advancing their education but paying new recruits a differential for the same increase in educational level, interviewing current employees for positions they have already promised to a "hand-picked" individual (wasting employees valuable time in order to meet interview quotas), posting, interviewing and selecting candidates for positions promising a pay increase but then retracting the positions altogether after the employees have gone through the entire process. This will always limit the organization's ability to achieve the highest level of quality - waste of resources.

pros: UVa has a well known reputation for its excellent in medical care having worked with many great doctors and being part of a team.  The divisions/departments have excellent support staff who really working hard to support the department/division in every aspect.  Charlottesville is a typical college type town though it is growing and is a great place to live.  UVa is the predominant employer here also.  Depending on your position involving interaction with UVa it can be really an enriching experience.   If you are lucky/fortunate to work in a division that does value their staff, the experience is beneficial for all.
cons: Speaking from the level of lower than management, staff don't receive the respect and recognition needed.  In fact, certain sections need a management over-haul and/or re-education in current HR do's and don'ts.  Some management actually add a caustic environment to some divisions with pettiness, letting things fall through the cracks, not interested in hearing issues that are of interest to those behind the counters and desks that are the first line of many departments.  Stress levels add to this.

pros:
- Very supportive of new graduate nurses, gives plenty of support through the transition from student to nurse
- Pay was comparable to other hospitals in the region
- Nurses had a strong leadership / voice on my unit
- Very visible management (including the executive officers)
- Felt appreciated for the work I did, by both unit management and executive management
cons:
- Staffing; it's an issue at most hospitals without ratios but we were frequently understaffed
- Difficult to take breaks (goes back to staffing)
- HIGH turn over rate for newer nurses

pros: Nice enough place to work, co-workers were great, wants to get better.  Seem to really care about patient safety and having nice, new facilities.
cons: Lowish pay, don't have to pay a lot as there isn't much competition in a small town.  Seem to focus on cost cutting in weird inefficient ways, punishing people (employees) when more obvious cuts go unnoticed (supply costs).

pros: 8 weeks of paid maternity leave + the use of short term disability if you quality.  Slow paced work environment, but every department is different. Health benefits are good and don't cost you a lot out of pocket.
cons: Blatant pushing of liberal ideas at every corner, from watch parties of the impeachment hearings to management saying all conservatives are unintelligent.  You are required to have MMR, tDAP and the flu shot and they refuse to give religious exemptions as the state legally requires.  You will be fired if you do not comply. Pay is low and HR will low ball you - Always counter their first offer.

pros: I get a paycheck. Benefits were cheap. People are nice. Easy access to public transportation. Lots of people of color in the executive staff, including the CEO. Management was very supportive in me achieving my career goals, even if it meant leaving UVA to do so. I had a nice going-away party.
cons:
Low pay, understaffed, burnout. 

UVA is cheap when it comes to their employees. They make them use their PTO if their clinic is closed for a holiday. Every time we had an event that involved food, it was a potluck. The departments were too cheap to have anything catered like my new job. 

The salaries are not competitive, and they don't seem like they care about promoting their employees from within; they would rather bring on an external applicant than work with someone working at the hospital already. Once I realized that I moved on. 

The environment was toxic. Our Gallup poll results were abysmal, and we were rated below average with every single question in the poll. The employees are not engaged at all. There was so much negativity going on in that clinic that I couldn't wait to leave. I think the entire clinic except the clerical staff is going to quit at one point if they keep things the way they are.

review_title: Great place to work if you have a good attitude and don't mind being a force for good!
pros: Great opportunities to learn! There are places for everyone to contribute if they are willing and currently they are open to improving from the status quo.
cons: Thought of as more of a number than a person. The pay is low if you are loyal to the hospital, but if you don't mind leaving for a couple years, then you can come back and get quite the significant raise. Very strange mentality rewarding disloyalty.

pros: The only pro to working here was the good health insurance option, PTO allowance and the promise of retirement in 20 years.
cons: The people in my department were uneducated, racist, impossible to work with. Management was not flexible with scheduling at all. If my kid was sick and I couldn't come it, there was no flex time. The pay was crap and they give false promise of easy growth. When I tried to transfer for another dept. because I was miserable there and had just graduated college, I was fired a week later.

review_title: Great pay, but if you want to be valued, work elsewhere
pros:
Excellent pay and benefits
Opportunities to participate in nursing research and evidence based practice
cons:
Unchecked bullying, especially of new employees
Great place to work if you don't want to be valued for your talents and knowledge

pros: Teaching hospital, room for clinical growth, diverse patient population, pharmacy technician support is consistent, training opportunities, lots of projects to take ownership of. Overall ideal outpatient pharmacy set up and experience.
cons: Pay, technicians not utilized to full potential, parking is offsite and there is a commute/shuttle to work areas (adds a minimum of 20mins one way onto work commute and must move from parking for events no matter what shift is being worked, constant emails about alternative parking locations due to events)

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Charlottesville, VA
pros: I worked in the medical ICU for many years. Management there was wonderful.
cons: Problem with the upper levels of management within the hospital system is that they know nothing about patient care. They seem to not be as caring towards staff either.

job_title: Ambulatory Administrative Coordinator in Charlottesville, VA
pros: I love the dream our UVA president has for this massive institution. I want to see everyone succeed and it's clear that the people hired on the inside want to see the same thing. :)
cons: The pay is very specified and mediocre. But it has gotten better since Jim Ryan announced UVA's new minimum wage of $15/hr.

pros: Great colleagues and team atmosphere within my department.
cons: High turnover in senior leadership and loss of integral clinician leaders as a result. Nurses and support staff appear short-staffed. Company is reactive rather than proactive in terms of staffing all areas.

pros: The University of Virginia Health Systems provides a competitive place to work and encourages career growth within the departement. They offer a great benefit package.
cons: The University of Virginia Health Systems main drawback is parking.  Free parking is offered, but is a 15 minute bus ride from the hospital.

pros: Working in the UVA hospital allows for the an easy commute and a convenient location for dining and after work activities.
cons: Transitioning to full time and dealing with the human resources department whatsoever is a hassle and often times frustrating.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Charlottesville, VA
pros: UVA hospital is a state hospital and if you're interested in pursuing a career in health care, it's a great place to start because here you can see a lot of cases that other private hospitals don't have.
cons: Because it's a state hospital, compared to other private hospitals such as Martha Jefferson, the facilities is not as competent.

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator & Reporting Analyst in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Loved doing heavy technical work in Healthcare data analysis and reporting. Very rewarding to help drive positive change in the health system.
cons: Management is not technical, and the environment runs under a variable reinforcement schedule. What is acceptable one day is rescinded the next.

pros: Strong community of nurses, great moral, challenging patient population. This is the first place I have worked where I felt my opinion as a bedside RN was actually asked for and cared about.
cons: Stinks when we get floated so often because census is low. But overall grateful to have a job that is willing to give us work.

pros: The Benefits are great, the people are great... for the most part.  You may be able to schedule your own hours.
cons: Raises very slow to come.  If you are an administrative staff instead of clinical staff member, it is difficult be get promoted, even if you have a 4-year degree.

pros: Diverse fields of medicine and surgery; amazing medical advances
cons: Have "old guard" where people continue to come to work and do not pull their weight, very hard to fire anyone

pros:
1. Benefits
2. Schedule
3. Health Club Discount
cons:
1. Having to use my PTO for Holidays.
2. Low Pay.
3. Working Holidays and Weekends (current position).
4. They take too long for recruitment.
4. Communication between Management and entry level has a lot to be desired.

job_title: Clinical Laboratory Scientist II in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Very friendly staff. Various opportunities. Teaching hospital so you get to see different things. Benefits are pretty good. Manager is very involved with his employees
cons: Salary not competitive enough for the cost of living in Charlottesville. Too many people working in one shift so there's not enough to do

pros:
good benefits
good people to with with
flexible working environment
cons: a lot of work to go around with no incentive to do better than your coworkers because they don't give individual raises in my department

pros: Extremely high ceiling for advancement, excellent pay and benefits.
cons: Very few.  Rigidity of schedule within a health care system is to be expected.

pros:
Function independently

Actively involved medical director with a passion for teaching
cons:
Aging equipment

Self-involved management

No permanent station for critical care staff and the stations assigned are typically cramped, closet-sized areas.

job_title: Patient Care Tech in Lynchburg, VA
pros: This employer has great benefits, that's a big reason for me to work here.
cons: The management at the UVA Lynchburg Dialysis  unit is not as good as you might expect.

review_title: Great hospital for community health care and research in a lovely charming town.
job_title: Research Laboratory Specialist Intermediate in Charlottesville, VA
pros: Access to top of the line equipment, great integration of clinical care and research
cons: Good old boys club, administration does not advocate for employees.

review_title: Large organization with great benefits but slow innovation
pros: Great benefits, upward mobility, job security
cons: horrible parking situation, out of date software, challenges to innovation due to large burrocracy

pros:
Everyone is empathetic and cooperative
Supervisors are very easy to work with
cons: Due to the company being so small and people often work off-site, you are often the only person in the office

pros:
supportive collaborators 
mentors are really helpful with getting your foot in the door for other opportunities

pros: Good pay/benefits, a lot of resources within the hospital to help nurses
cons: more so have had problems with short staffing for nurses nationwide, no problems with UVA as a system

pros: Highly clinical, patient centered care, positive management

pros: Great town and great benefits.
cons: Pretty much a fixed salary.  Minimal chance for promotion or pay raise.  I'm sure its better for a certified health professional.

pros: Good Salary, Charlottesville is a beautiful place to live and raise a family.
cons: Very Political and slow to change. No accountability throughout organization.

pros: Good pay. Nice area.  Rank and file are a dedicated bunch who care greatly about patient care.
cons: Meta-work. They spend more time time talking about work that actually doing it. Culture of fear nd mistrust. So called accountability culture goes only one way. Numerous meetings about irrelevant things. Parking is a problem. Politics-politics-politics.

pros: Analytical Focus on Patient Care provides great value to the organization
cons: Architectural disciplines are very immature ...
